questions.text: A 28 y/o reports a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) five years ago but is otherwise healthy. She does not smoke and has no other significant medical history. She desires a reliable, long-term contraceptive method. Which of the following contraceptive options is MOST contraindicated in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Adverse Effects of Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs)

Contraindications of Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs)

Cardiovascular Effects (due to estrogen content)

  • Myocardial infarction (MI)
  • Cerebral thrombosis - Stroke
  • Risk increases with age >35 and cigarette smoking.
 

Carcinogenesis

  • Increased risk of cervical cancer
 

Metabolic Effects (due to progesterone content)

  • Elevated blood pressure
  • Altered serum lipid levels
  • Interference with blood clotting
  • Interference with carbohydrate metabolism
 

Thromboembolic Events

  • Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
  • Pulmonary embolism (PE)
 

Others

  • Lactation: Reduced quantity and quality of breast milk
  • Weight gain
  • Migraine
  • Breast tenderness

Absolute Contraindications:

  • Cancer of the breast and genitals
  • Liver disease
  • Previous or present history of thromboembolism
  • Cardiac abnormalities
  • Congenital hyperlipidaemia
  • DM with vasculopathy
  • Migraine with aura
  • Undiagnosed vaginal bleed 
  • Suspected pregnancy
 

Relative Contraindications (requiring medical surveillance):

  • Age over 40 years
  • Smoking and age over 35 years
  • Mild hypertension
  • Chronic renal disease
  • Migraine

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of a planned family?

options.label: A
options.text: No childbirth beyond the age of 30-35

options.label: B
options.text: Gap of 2 years between marriage and first child birth

options.label: C
options.text: Age of mother is >20 years at the time of first child birth

options.label: D
options.text: Gap of 2 years between 2 successive pregnancies

questions.correct_answer: D. Gap of 2 years between 2 successive pregnancies

questions.text: In a village with a population of 2,000 eligible couples, the survey findings revealed that 600 couples use oral contraceptives, 300 couples use condoms, 200 couples use intrauterine devices (IUDs), and 100 couples have undergone sterilization. Which of the following is the couple protection rate (CPR)?
Which of the following statements correctly defines the Pearl Index for measuring contraceptive effectiveness?
questions.explanation:
Formula

(Total accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure) x 1200

Numerator

The total number of accidental pregnancies, including pregnancies that resulted in live births, stillbirths, abortions, or are ongoing.

Denominator

(Total months in the review period) – (months stopped using contraception for non-pregnancy reasons)

Minimum Data

At least 600 months of exposure.

Disadvantages
  • PI assumes a constant failure rate over time, but contraceptive failure rates typically decline with longer use.
  • High-fertility couples conceive earlier, skewing results towards lower-fertility couples later in studies.
  • PI ignores factors beyond accidental pregnancy that affect effectiveness, like user dissatisfaction, side effects, attempts to conceive, or loss of follow-up.

Better methods

Life Table Analysis is a better method to evaluate contraceptive efficacy.

It calculates cumulative failure rates over a specified time frame, like one

month.

questions.text: Match the following contraceptive methods with their appropriate failure rates. Contraceptive Failure Rate A. Male condom 1. 9-20/HWY B. Female Condom 2. 20-40/HWY C. Diaphragm 3. 6-12/HWY D. Vaginal sponge (Nulliparous women) 4. 2-14/HWY E. Vaginal sponge (Parous women) 5. 5-21/HWY
questions.explanation:
Contraceptive Method

Failure Rate
(Pregnancies per 100 women-years)

Additional Information

Male Condom

2-13

The most common cause of failure is incorrect use.

Female Condom

5-21

Higher failure rate than male condoms.

Diaphragm

6-12

Not recommended under the National Family Planning Welfare Programme.

Vaginal sponge

9-20

Higher failure rate in parous women (20-40/HWY) compared to nulliparous women. 

Spermicides

High

High failure rate when used alone, but good to use with some other contraceptive method.

Method

Pregnancies per 100 women years

Injectables

0.05

Implant

0.1

Vasectomy

0.1

OCP

0.3

Hormonal IUD

0.5

Tubal ligation

0.5

Copper IUD

0.6

Calendar method

14

Withdrawal

20

questions.text: Match the following: a) Mission Parivar Vikas 1) Contraception counselling method b) NISCHAY 2) Population stabilization fund c) Jansankhya sthirata kosh 3) Nayi pahel kit- family planning kit for newly weds d) Gather approach 4) Home testing UPT provided by ASHA
questions.explanation:
Mission Parivar Vikas
  • Aims to promote family planning and reduce the population
  • Nayi pahel kit- family planning kit for newlyweds
  • Saas bahu samelan- encourages daughter-in-law and mother-in-law to discuss family planning
  • Saarthi- family planning mobile van

NISCHAY
  • Home testing UPT provided by ASHA

 

Jansankhya sthirata kosh
  • Population stabilization fund

Gather approach
  • Contraception counselling method
  • Stands for Greet, Ask, Tell, Help, Explain, and Return

questions.text: What program is the given image a logo for?
A 29-year-old woman with 3 children has come for counselling regarding sterilisation. She is hesitant to have surgery. Which of the following methods suits her needs?
Which of the following is false regarding female sterilisation?

options.label: A
options.text: Minilap can be performed at PHC level

options.label: B
options.text: Permission of spouse must be obtained

options.label: D
options.text: They must be of age 22-49 years

questions.correct_answer: B. Permission of spouse must be obtained
questions.explanation:
Procedure

Timing

Interval sterilization

Any time after 6 weeks of childbirth

Postpartum sterilization

Between 24 hours to 7 days of delivery

Sterilization with MTP

Concurrently

Sterilisation following spontaneous abortion

Within 7 days (if no other complications)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is ready for discharge after vasectomy under his family planning program. How long should he use additional contraceptive measures till he becomes completely sterile?

options.label: A
options.text: No need of additional contraceptive measures

questions.text: In the Basal body temperature method, which of the following is the reason for increase in body temperature?
questions.explanation:
Calendar/Rhythm method

 
  •   Intercourse should be avoided on 11th to 17th day of menstrual cycle
 
  • Ova remains viable for 12-24 hrs.
 
  • Not preferred since menstrual cycles are not always regular.

Basal Body Temperature method:

 
  • Prior to ovulation, the basal body temperature increases by 0.3 to 0.5 degree Celsius.
 
  • The increase in temperature is due to an increase in progesterone (Option B).
 
  • This method is reliable if the intercourse is restricted to the post ovulatory phase, after 3 days of temperature rise.

Cervical mucus/Billings method:
  • This method is based on changes in characteristics of cervical mucus observed as the menstrual cycle proceeds.
 
  • During ovulation, cervical mucus becomes watery, smooth, slippery and profuse resembling raw egg white.
 
  • After ovulation, cervical mucus thickens and decreases in quantity, due to increase in progesterone.
 
  • This method requires a high level of motivation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an emergency contraceptive?
questions.explanation:
Emergency contraception

MOA

How to use(hrs after unprotected sexual intercourse)

Copper containing IUD (most effective)

Causes a chemical reaction and prevents fertilization

Should be inserted within 120 hours (99% effective)

Levonorgestrel (i-pill) (option C)

Progesterone thickens cervical mucus and decreases tubal motility

1.5 mg single tablet or two doses of 0.75 mg 12 hours apart within 72 hours

Ulipristal (option A)

 Selective progesterone receptor down regulator

30 mg single tablet within 120 hours

Mifepristone (option B)

Makes endometrium unsuitable for implantation

10 mg single dose within 72 hours

Yuzpee method (not used now)

Prevents implantation and thickens cervical mucus

Two doses of 0.1 mg ethinylestradiol and 0.5 mg levonorgestrel, 12 hours apart, within 72 hours

questions.text: A woman missed 2 pills in the second week of her contraceptive pack. She had unprotected sex yesterday. What should she do?

options.label: A
options.text: Discard the pack and start a new one immediately

options.label: B
options.text: Take 2 pills at the scheduled time

options.label: C
options.text: Skip the missed pills and continue with the next pack

questions.correct_answer: B. Take 2 pills at the scheduled time
questions.explanation:
Missed pills

Management

Missed 1 or 2 pills/ started new pack 1 or

2 days late
  • Take one pill as soon as possible or take 2 pills at the scheduled time: No risk of pregnancy

Missed 3 or more pills in the first or second week/ started a new pack 3 or more days late
  • Take one pill as soon as possible, and then continue with the scheduled pill
  • Use the backup method for the next 7 days
  • In case of unprotected sex in the last 72 hours, use an emergency contraceptive method

Missed 3 or more pills in the third week (last week)
  • Take one pill as soon as possible and finish the rest of the hormonal pills
  • The last 7 non – hormonal pills should be discarded, start a new pack the next day
  • Use a barrier method for the next 7 days
  • In case of unprotected sex in the last 7 days, use emergency contraception

questions.text: A 30 Y/o woman has been taking oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for the past five years, not just for contraception but also for managing her menstrual cramps and acne. Which of the following are additional long-term health benefits of OCPs, aside from birth control and symptomatic relief?
questions.correct_answer: C. Reduced risk of ovarian cancer

questions.text: A 30-year-old sexually active couple presents at a free health clinic seeking advice on contraception methods that also protect against sexually transmitted infections (STIs). They are interested in a method that offers both protection from pregnancy and protection against STDs. Which barrier method would be most recommended for them?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Male Condom

Female Condom

Diaphragm

Material

Latex

Polyurethane or Nitrile/latex

Synthetic rubber or plastic

Spermicide Requirement

Optional

Pre-lubricated with silicone; spermicide not required

Used with spermicide

Protection against STDs

Protects both partners from STDs

Protects against STDs 

Doesn't protect from HIV and STDs

Failure rate

2-13/HWY

5-21/HWY

6-12/HWY

Advantages

Safe, easy to use, inexpensive, no side effects, easy disposable
  • No Hormonal side effects.
  • Can be used by women with latex sensitivity.
  • Can be reused.

Nil side effects and medical contraindications, reusable

Disadvantages
  • May slip off or tear due to incorrect use
  • Interferes with sexual sensation
  • Interferes with sexual sensation
  • May slip off or tear
  • High cost, noticeable during sex, needs practice to insert and use
  • Should be present in vagina up to 6 hours post-ejaculation,
  • Risk of Toxic Shock Syndrome (TSS) if left for > 24 hours

Brand Name(s)

NIRODH

FEMIDOM

Variations of diaphragm:Cervical cap, Vault cap, Vimule cap, Dutch cap

Availability

Freely available under the National Family Welfare Programme

Provided under the National AIDS Control Programme (NACP)

Not recommended under the National Family Planning Welfare Programme

Other Information

Should not be reused most

Reusable; male and female condoms should not be used together due to an anti-synergistic effect

questions.text: Match the following contraceptive methods with their correct descriptions: Contraceptive Method Description A. Femilon 1. A non-hormonal male contraceptive derived from cottonseed oil. B. Mini Pills 2. A combined oral contraceptive pill containing both estrogen and progesterone. C. Gossypol 3. A progestin-only oral contraceptive pill.
questions.explanation:
Contraceptive Method

Composition

Mechanism of Action

Target Population

Femilon
(Combined OCP)

Ethinyl estradiol IP (0.02 mg) and Desogestrel BP (0.15 mg) - Ultra low dose

Inhibits ovulation by suppressing pituitary secretion of gonadotropin

Women

Mini pills

(Progesterone only pill)

Progesterone

Inhibits ovulation, thickens cervical mucus, inhibits tubal motility, delays sperm and ovum transport

Older women, women who cannot use combined pills due to cardiovascular risks, women who are lactating

Gossypol
(Non-hormonal male contraceptivel)

Natural phenol, a derivative of cotton-seed oil

Inhibits spermatogenesis

Men

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the difference between MALA-N and MALA-D?

options.label: A
options.text: MALA-N: Contains only progesterone; MALA-D: Contains both estrogen and progesterone

options.label: B
options.text: MALA-N: Available for free under the government program; MALA-D: Sold at a subsidised price

options.label: C
options.text: MALA-N: Taken daily; MALA-D: Taken weekly

options.label: D
options.text: MALA-N: Injectable contraceptive; MALA-D: Oral contraceptive

questions.correct_answer: B. MALA-N: Available for free under the government program; MALA-D: Sold at a subsidised price
questions.explanation:
Feature

MALA-N

MALA-D

Availability
(Option B)

Supplied free of cost through PHCs, urban family welfare centers.

Available at a subsidized price of Rs. 3 per packet through social marketing schemes

Composition

(Option A)

Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg and Ethinyl estradiol 0.03 mg

Packaging

(Option D)

Packet of 28 tablets - 21 white pills containing the hormones and 7 brown film-coated tablets containing 60 mg ferrous fumarate

Mechanism of action
  • Prevents ovulation
  • Prevents implantation
  • Thick cervical secretions

Effectiveness

100% effective if taken correctly 

Failure rate with typical use is 0.8%

questions.text: A 38 y/o woman presents to a clinic seeking contraception counseling. She is a breastfeeding mother of a 3-month-old baby. She reports a history of heavy menstrual bleeding. Which of the following can be given to her?
questions.explanation:
Centchroman (Ormeloxifene)

Brand Name

Saheli (formerly); Chhaya (currently)

Type of Contraceptive

Non-hormonal, selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM)

Mechanism of Action

Delays ovulation, alters the endometrial lining to prevent implantation

Dosage

One 30mg tablet twice a week for the first 3 months, followed by one tablet weekly thereafter

Advantages
  • Non-hormonal, minimal side effects
  • Convenient weekly dosage
  • No impact on breastfeeding
  • Protective effect against breast and endometrial cancer.

Disadvantages

Has a high failure rate attributed to low compliance with the prescribed dosing schedule.

Additional Uses

Dysfunctional uterine bleeding

Contraindications

PCOD, Thromboembolic disorders, severe liver dysfunction

Availability

Included in the National Family Welfare program, making it available free of charge at sub-centers

questions.text: A 28 y/o woman desires a reliable method that she can manage herself and wants to avoid daily pill-taking. She has no history of cardiovascular disease or other contraindications for combined hormonal contraception. Which of the following offers both estrogen and progesterone and would be suitable for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Contraceptive Method

Hormone Type

Benefits

Form

Duration of Effectiveness

NuvaRing
(Option A)

Estrogen (Ethinyl Estradiol) and Progesterone (Etonogestrel)

Lower Estrogen exposure than with OCPs.

Low incidence of estrogenic S/E.

Low incidence of irregular bleeding.

Vaginal Ring

1 month

ANTARA

(Option B)

Progesterone (Medroxyprogesterone Acetate)

Long-lasting and reversible.

Injectable (Depo-Provera)

3 months

NORPLANT

(Option C)

Progesterone (Levonorgestrel)

Used during lactation because it has progesterone and no estrogen.

Subdermal Implants

Up to 5 years

NET-EN

(Option D)

Progesterone
(Norethisterone Enanthate)

Long-lasting and reversible.

Injectable

8 weeks

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents for contraceptive counselling. She has a history of irregular menstrual cycles and desires a long-acting reversible contraceptive method. She is not currently pregnant and has no recent history of pelvic infections. Her last menstrual period was two weeks ago, and she is not currently using any form of contraception. When is the most appropriate time for the gynecologist to insert the intrauterine device (IUD) for this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: At any time during her cycle

options.label: D
options.text: Two weeks before her next menstrual period

questions.correct_answer: A. During her current menstrual cycle
questions.explanation:
Ideal time
  • During menstruation or within the first 10 days of the start of period

Preferred time
  • Postpartum (immediate postpartum): Post-placenta insertion; Has a higher rate of expulsion
  • Late postpartum: Within 48 hours of delivery up to 1 week

Other times
  • Post-puerperal: After 6-8 weeks of delivery
  • Post-coital: Up to 3-5 days after unprotected intercourse.
  • Post-abortion: After 1st trimester loss.
    • Not recommended after a 2nd trimester abortion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an absolute contraindication to IUD insertion?
questions.explanation:
Condition Contraindication Type Reason
Suspected pregnancy (Option A) Absolute Risk of interfering with existing pregnancy
Cervical cancer (Ca cervix) (Option B) Absolute Risk of bleeding/infection, treatment takes priority
Current pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) (Option D) Absolute IUD could worsen infection and lead to complications
Menorrhagia Relative (not absolute) May worsen bleeding, but not a strict contraindication; copper IUDs are avoided, but LNG-IUS (like Mirena) is actually used to treat menorrhagia
Condition Rationale
Pregnancy or suspected pregnancy Risk of miscarriage or infection
Current pelvic infections (PID, endometritis, TB) Increased risk of exacerbation and spread of infection
Mucopurulent cervicitis or untreated STIs Insertion may worsen infection
Recent puerperal or septic abortion (<3 months) Higher infection risk
Cervical or endometrial cancer May cause trauma or interfere with treatment
Gestational trophoblastic disease with elevated β-hCG Risk of uterine perforation or spread
Unexplained abnormal vaginal bleeding Need to exclude serious pathology before insertion
Uterine abnormalities distorting the cavity Can prevent proper placement and increase risk of perforation
Allergy to IUD components e.g., copper allergy (copper IUD), levonorgestrel allergy (hormonal IUD)
Wilson’s disease (for copper IUDs) Copper accumulation is contraindicated
Current breast cancer (for hormonal IUDs) Hormonal exposure may worsen estrogen-sensitive malignancies

Condition Considerations
Resolved GTD with falling β-hCG May be safe if levels are undetectable
High risk of STIs (e.g., multiple partners) May increase infection risk post-insertion
Complicated transplant history May impair immune response or healing
Advanced AIDS (not clinically well) Higher infection risk and complications
Coagulopathies or severe anemia May worsen bleeding, particularly with copper IUDs
Past history of PID, STIs, or ectopic pregnancy Not absolute, but requires counseling and monitoring
Certain chronic conditions (e.g., SLE, liver disease) Hormonal IUDs need evaluation of risk of worsening disease

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with complaints of persistent lower abdominal pain and fever. She had a copper-releasing intrauterine device inserted nine months ago for contraception. She has multiple sexual partners. On examination, she appears uncomfortable, and her abdomen is tender to palpation in the lower quadrants. Pelvic examination reveals no visible IUD strings. Her vital signs show a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F). What is the most likely complication associated with this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Side effects of IUDs

Bleeding
  • Most common side effect; physiological bleeding resolves in 1-3 months.
  • Iron supplementation may be needed.
  • Persistent bleeding despite treatment may necessitate IUD removal.

Pain
  • Most common cause for removal
  • Managed with analgesics.
  • Resolves in 3 months.
  • Severe pain may indicate uterine perforation (rare).

Pelvic inflammatory disease (Option C)
  • Presents with fever, abdominal pain, and discharge.
  • Treatment involves broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • IUD removal if no improvement.
  • 3rd generation of IUD is protective against IUD.

Uterine perforation (Option B)
  • Rare complications linked to immediate postpartum insertion or poor technique.
  • 1st generation IUDs are associated with a higher risk of perforation.

Failure of contraception ➜ pregnancy
  • Least pregnancies are reported with MIRENA.
  • If a woman requests an induced abortion – legally allowed.
  • If a woman wants to continue pregnancy and threads are visible:
    • Pull the thread and continue pregnancy.
    • Explain the risk of spontaneous abortion or congenital anomalies.
  • If a woman wants to continue pregnancy and threads are not visible:
    • Uterus examination for any complications. Evacuation of uterus if any complication is identified.
    • If no complication identified , pregnancy can be continued after removal of IUD if the woman desires with increased risk of spontaneous abortion and pre term labour. 

Ectopic pregnancy (Option D)
  • Recognized by lower abdominal pain, dark vaginal bleeding, or amenorrhea.
  • Women at high risk should avoid IUDs.

Expulsion
(Option A)
  • Typically occurs within weeks of insertion or during menstruation.
  • Higher risk in young, nulliparous, postpartum women or using 1st generation IUDs

Migration of IUD
  • Rarely causes intestinal obstruction.
  • Diagnosed via X-ray imaging if suspected.

questions.text: What is the name of the IUD shown below?
questions.explanation:
2nd generation IUDs

Type

Copper containing device

Mechanism of action
  • Reduces sperm motility and survival by
    • altering cervical mucus
    • affecting uterine enzymes
    • increasing cellular response in the endometrium

Features
  • Strong anti-fertility effect
  • Low expulsion rate
  • Easy to fit in nulliparous women
  • Lesser side effects
  • Effective post-coital contraceptive

Side effects
  • Bleeding
  • Pain
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Uterine perforation
  • Failure of contraception ➜ Pregnancy
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Expulsion
  • Migration of IUD

CuT 380A

  • 380 mm² of copper wire around a stem with nylon thread attached
  • Shelf life -10 years

Nova-T

  • CuT 380 A with a silver (Ag) core attached to it
  • Shelf life - 5 years

Multiload

  • U-shaped ring
  • Most commonly used IUD
  • CuT 375

IUDs

Shelf-life

CuT380 A

10 years

Nova-T

5 years

Progestasert

1 year

LNG IUD

5-8 years

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea seeks contraception counseling. She prefers a long-acting reversible contraceptive and is interested in intrauterine devices (IUDs). Which IUD would be the most appropriate choice for her, considering her medical history and preferences?
questions.explanation:
Types of IUDs
 

1st generation

2nd generation

3rd generation

Type

Inert

Copper-containing

Hormone containing

Examples

Lippes loop

CuT-380A

Mirena (LNG-20)

Grafenberg containing ring

Nova-T

Progestasert

Multiload

 

1st generation IUD

2nd generation IUD 

3rd generation IUD

Mechanism of action
  • Made of polyethene/other polymers
  • Foreign body reaction causes reduced chances of fertilization
  • Contains copper 
  • Copper acts as spermicide 
  • Copper changes composition of cervical mucus 
  • Releases levonorgestrel
  • Increases cervical mucus thickness
  • Makes endometrium unfavorable for implantation

Features
  • Non-medicated
  • High failure rate
  • Highly effective 
  • Low failure rate 

 
  • Lowest failure rate among IUDs
  • Decreases menstrual blood loss
  • More expensive

Examples
  • Grafenberg ring

 

  • Lippe’s loop

 

 

 
  • Nova-T (Noncard)
  • Multiload 250.

 
  • Mirena/LNG-20 (Releases 20μg of progesterone per day)

Shelf life- 5-8 years

  • Progestasert (Releases 65μg of progesterone per day)

Shelf life- 1 year

Side effects
  • Bleeding, Pain
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease- M/c/c Actinomyces
  • Uterine perforation
  • Failure of contraception ➜ Pregnancy
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Expulsion, Migration of IUD

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a form that spermicide is available in?
questions.explanation:
Type of contraception

Chemical barrier

Mechanism of action

Surface-active agents that attach to spermatozoa, inhibiting oxygen uptake and killing them.

Available as

Creams, Jellies, Pastes, Suppositories & Soluble films

Advantages

When used in conjunction with barrier methods, offers better pregnancy prevention than if either method were used alone

Disadvantages
  • Must be used immediately before intercourse and repeated before each sex act
  • Must be introduced into regions of the vagina where sperm are likely to be deposited
  • May cause burning, irritation, or messiness

Failure rate

High when used alone

Availability

Not part of the method mix promoted by the National Family Welfare Programme in India

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the contraception shown below?

options.label: A
options.text: It is made of polyurethane foam and saturated with a spermicide nonoxynol-9

options.label: B
options.text: It must be left in place for at least 6 hours after intercourse.

options.label: C
options.text: It offers no protection from sexually transmitted infections.

options.label: D
options.text: It has a lower failure rate in women who have given birth before.

questions.correct_answer: D. It has a lower failure rate in women who have given birth before.
questions.explanation:
Brand name

TODAY

Material

Small polyurethane foam sponge

Mechanism of action

Combines barrier and spermicidal methods to prevent conception Saturated with 1000 mg of spermicide ‘Non-oxynol-9’

Technique of use
  • Must be run under water till thoroughly wet before insertion
  • Inserted vaginally and must be ‘placed over the cervix to be effective
  • Must be left in place for 6 hours after ejaculation
  • All sponges must be removed within the time limits specified by the manufacturer (24 hours for Today)

Disadvantages
  • No protection from HIV or STDs
  • May lead to Toxic Shock Syndrome if left beyond 24 hours
  • Has to be left for 6 hours post ejaculation
  • Increased risk of yeast infection and UTI
  • Higher failure rate than diaphragm

Failure rate

Parous women: 20-40 per HWY

Nulliparous women: 9-20 per HWY

questions.text: Match the following contraceptives with their appropriate classification CATEGORY 1 CATEGORY 2 A. Spermicide 1. Physiological method B. Grafenberg Ring 2. Chemical barrier method C. Nuva rings 3. IUD D. Tubectomy 4. Hormonal contraceptive E. Coitus interruptus 5. Terminal surgical contraception
